What is standard gauge and why was it adopted?
Standard gauge is 1,435 mm (4 ft 8½ in). It became dominant due to interoperability and early British rail influence, which simplified rolling stock interchange and reduced costs.

Fixed-block divides track into discrete blocks with occupancy detection; trains enter only if a block is clear. Moving-block uses continuous train control (e.g., CBTC) to authorize movement based on real-time separation, reducing headways and increasing throughput.

Intermodal freight uses standardized containers that transfer between modes—ship, rail, and truck—without handling contents, improving efficiency and lowering costs.

When was the first full-scale steam locomotive built?
1804, by Richard Trevithick, demonstrated on the Penydarren tramroad in Wales.

Name three factors that influence railway capacity.
Signaling method (fixed vs moving block), train mix/speed differentials, and terminal/yard constraints.
